												A pretty fun decent game. Has pleasant graphics and solid smooth gameplay. The sound is good and the music is not bad. I wish I would have payed more attention to this when it came out in 2009 because I am having a good time playing it. Well mostly. The grappling swinging controls are not as awesome as a lot of user reviews would lead you to believe, but they are competent. The problem being that swing points are usually too close together making consistent swinging very awkward to do. It is also very hard to gauge when to release to swing outward correctly even though it shows you a blue icon letting you know when. You still have to pinpoint release to swing even remotely how you want to, which leads to a lot of swinging straight up or at a upward angle, or too low, as opposed to straight forward or at a much desired but very hard to do forward upward angle to propel you forward correctly. The third person shooting aspect is forgettable especially since the only weapon you have in the game is a pistol, although you can find secondary weapons sometimes like a minigun which blows, or a grenade launcher which rocks. You can also punch objects into the air then jump up and punch them at your enemy, or you can latch your grapple onto an object and whip it into them, or you can grapple onto an enemy and jump kick them twice to kill them. You can use the jump kick move for a lot of your kills.Some parts are not very fun. Mainly the part I just got passed. It didn't make any sense but up until this point, about 4-5 hours into the game, everything was very easy, then all of a sudden I had to fight two robots and the difficulty spiked massively from a 2 to a 9 and they are not even bosses, just regular enemies. They are not exactly fun to fight until I just swung objects into them with swing grapple and on like my 5+ try I killed them.Overall it was a solid purchase. I think I payed $2.50 for it and at that price it was a very good deal. Do not pay more than $5 though because it is a pretty short game. 7/10

												This is hands down one of the worst games I have ever played. The graphics are the best part of the game, which isnt saying allot, but the animation, controls and physics are ridiculously bad. Under no circumstances should anyone ever buy this game. Remember how frustrating the NES game could become, this is that times 1000. They could have made a great game but instead they decided to make the controls so bad and laggy that just trying to swing from one beam to another is a test of your patience. Once you're locked on to a beam, rather than having to swing back and forth building momentum the guy goes from 0 to 100 instantly. That isnt so bad except if you want to have forward moentum after you release you must do it a good 2 seconds earlier than it appears you should because the character wont release when you release the button. The combination of these two things makes knowing when to let go and how far your character will go once you release impossible to know for sure. I eventually grew to like the NES game because of it's dificulty, but this game is just maddening because of how they created that dificulty. If the dificulty was a result of the environments and enemies that would be fine, but the difficulty comes from the horrible controls, impossible physics and crappy character animation. The enemy AI is awful as well, they just huddle into groups so you can just mow them down in a line. The story is preposterously awful and the voice acting is so bad it makes the cut scenes unwatchable.

												The world of Bionic Commando is a blast to traverse and it is oddly satisfying to play around with Spencer's bionic arm. While I recommend Bionic Commando, there are a few things that detracted from my experience that I feel are worth discussing. The story is a zany military conspiracy satire of sorts that isn't and shouldn't be taken too seriously. Characters are rather flat and predictable. The protagonist in particular is almost impossible to empathize with due to his violent and cliche behavior. That being said, I would like to stress that Bionic Commando is all about the power trip you receive from the gameplay, not the story so Spencer's lackluster tragedy is acceptable. While enemy soldiers pose an appropriate threat most of the time, the sheer volume of enemies in the later sections is more annoying than fun. Mech enemies in particular are a chore to face in the higher difficulty settings because the amount of time it takes to set up an attack leaves the player open to sniper fire. The unforgiving enemy placement rewards cowardly tactics that goes against the power trip philosophy of the game.Finally, without spoiling too much of the game, the later boss fights are poorly executed. Instead of making interesting use of the bionic arm mechanics, these fights boil down to waiting for your turn to attack then entering a prompt to deliver the final blow. Overall these are nitpicky complaints. The game is great and consider giving it a shot if you're on the fence of a purchase.

												!SPOILERS AHEAD!Please note, this review is written in bullet-point form, as that's all it deserves.What Bionic Commando did right:Large, open areas idea for free-roaming with the grappleGood use of grapple/momentum technologyLarge, glowing hidden objects, requires skill  as well as finding themSatisfying use of the grapple system to throw or throw at enemiesInteresting use of challenges to reward upgradesNice use of enemy dialoguePlayed on Hard first time – difficult, but not impossibleWhat it did wrong:Last-gen use of checkpoint system with very few checkpointsInstant death pitfalls, invisible walls, fire and waterLimited incentive to collect hidden objectsHidden items requiring very risky jumps that will easily kill you and require you to start againClunky aiming systemSome long, vulnerable animations (Kiteing)Very basic gun systemLimited use for the melee systemClunky in-game menuGeneric hide-to-heal health systemEnemies see you from far too far away, no stealth elementBadly voiced, unlikeable main characterTenuous plot, badly written scriptGigantic plot holes: What is the 'item'; What did they plan to do with it; Who is the 'Sniper; What is the purpose of Mag's character (dies); Main character's unclear death at the end; Giant army of angel robots out of nowhere; Absurd betrayal for no clear reason; Main character's wife died so he could have a robotic arm, doesn't seem to bother him; Who are any of these characters (supposedly from previous games)Terrible quick-time-esque final bossUnskippable creditsWhat it should have done:Melee system like Batman: Arkham AsylumUse of time-slow while aimingHeal back only the last full chuck of health on a bar of partsDecoy weapon/item to lure large groups away/togetherCONCLUSION:This game is clunky, flawed, and written like a bad fan-fiction... but there is some fun to be had here. You may get frustrated, you may find it unfulfilling, but if you get this cheap on sale... why the hell not? And let's make this very clear: I'm recommending this because "why not". It's not good, you won't love it, but there isn't a "meh" button for me to choose.
